description: From earlier hugge (“to embrace, clasp with the arms”) (1560), probably representing a conflation of huck (“to crouch, huddle down”) and Old Norse hugga (“to comfort, console”), from hugr (“mind, heart, thought”), from Proto-Germanic *hugiz (“mind, thought, sense”), cognate with Icelandic hugga (“to comfort”), Old English hyġe (“thought”) (whence high (Etymology 2)).

entries.meaning: A close embrace, especially when charged with such an emotion as represented by: affection, joy, relief, lust, anger, aggression, compassion, and the like, as opposed to being characterized by formality, equivocation or ambivalence (a half-embrace or "little hug").

verbs.description: hug (third-person singular simple present hugs, present participle hugging, simple past and past participle hugged)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To crouch; to huddle as with cold.
(transitive) To embrace by holding closely, especially in the arms.
examples: Billy hugged Danny until he felt better.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To stay close to (the shore etc.)
(transitive, figurative) To hold fast; to cling to; to cherish.
